##Form 131 Analytical Reasoning - Answer explanations

###Welcome to Khan Academy! 

We've partnered with the Law School Admissions Council provide free test preparation for the LSAT. 

This article provides answer explanations for Form 131. To find more practice and help content, go to http://khanacademy.org/prep/lsat.

---

##Prompt 1 - Witness testimonies

[[☃ explanation 1]]

[[☃ explanation 2]]*********************************************

*This initial setup is very important! Answer explanations will refer to the "Scenarios" we develop through our initial deductions.

---

options.explanation:
The participants in an experiment designed to evaluate the persuasive impact of expert witness testimony will be divided into six groups, according to occupation—judges, lawyers, medical doctors, nurses, police officers, and teachers. The six groups will be evaluated separately, one after the other, in accordance with the following conditions:

The teachers must be evaluated at some time before the medical doctors and at some time before the nurses.

The medical doctors must be evaluated at some time before the lawyers.

The nurses must be evaluated either immediately before or immediately after the police officers.

The police officers must be evaluated at some time between the judges and the lawyers, regardless of whether the judges are evaluated before the lawyers or after.

###What the setup tells us

We’re essentially putting six groups of witnesses in order. At first glance, it might seem like we need to group the individual participants, but that ends up being descriptive background info that won’t affect our diagram. We are **ordering** **Judges**, **Lawyers**, **Medical**, **Nurses**, **Police**, and **Teachers**. Since the six groups will be evaluated separately and one after the other, your initial diagram might look like this:

[[☃ image 1]]

###What do the rules tell us?

* **Rule 1:** The **Teachers** are at some time before the **Medical doctors** and at some time before the **Nurses**. We can note this *relative* ordering using dashes. Keep in mind that we don’t know 1) how much actual time separates the elements, and 2) what the relationship is between **Medical doctors** and **Nurses**.

* **Rule 2:** The **Medical doctors** are at some time before the **Lawyers**. Again, we can note this rule down. Some students like to combine rules as they go, so they might note this rule as an attachment to Rule 1; for simplicity’s sake, we’ll keep all of the rules separate until we get to the Deductions stage.

* **Rule 3:** The **Nurses** are either immediately before or immediately after the **Police**. This rule *does* tell us about actual spacing, so we can mark it **NP or PN**. 

* **Rule 4:** The **Police** are at some time between the **Judges** and the **Lawyers**, but we *don’t* know the relative order of the **Judges** and **Lawyers**, so we can create another “or” statement:

[[☃ image 2]]

###What can we deduce?

All of our rules involve Groups of elements! So, we can definitely look for Repeat elements and connect rules that way, creating bigger and bigger groups. But first: we have an ideal opportunity to create Multiple Scenarios from Rule 4. Either **J—P—L** is true, or **L—P—J** is true, and from there, we can build out each scenario further using the other rules’ Groups. 

**Scenario 1:** **J—P—L**

* Rule 3 tells us that **NP** is a pair, but we’ll want to make sure we remember that it could be **NP** *or* **PN**. There are a number of ways to mark this; we’ll show you two and you can choose the one that seems clearer to you.
* We can add Rule 2 (**M—L**) to the **Lawyers** we’ve already marked.
* We can also add Rule 1 (**T—M**) and attach it to the **M** here.
* Likewise, we know that **T—N**, so we can note that dash to complete this scenario:

[[☃ image 3]]

**Scenario 2:** **L—P—J**

* In this scenario, we can once again add **N** in order to make the **PN** or **NP** pair. Again, we’ll show you two different ways to note this.
* We’ll add Rule 2 (**M—L**), and
* We’ll add Rule 1 (**T—M**).
* Note that we don’t need to connect **T** and **N**, since this scenario’s diagram already makes it clear that **T** is earlier than **N**:

[[☃ image 4]]

We’ll opt for the first way of noting the **PN** or **NP** pair for the remainder of these explanations. Our final diagram looks like this:

[[☃ image 5]]

The Multiple Scenarios make our job a lot easier: every acceptable situation that conforms to this setup’s rules will fit into one of these two scenarios! And if you have a “new-if” question that places an element into a specific spot, you can use the dashed diagram that we initially came up with if it’s not already clear from our Scenarios what the answer is. 

**Important note:** These dashes represent *relative* ordering. If two elements are not connected in a linear way, we cannot deduce their relationship. For example, in Scenario 1, we have no way of knowing whether **Judges** or **Medical doctors** are earlier! So, don’t be “visual” when interpreting these diagrams—don’t assume that “farther left” means “earlier”. Use the dashes to understand what relationships we know and what relationships we don’t know. If it’s helpful to you, many students like to pretend that the dashes are “stretchy” so that they don’t fall into the trap of interpreting the diagrams visually.

Let’s tackle the questions using our final diagram.

###Question 1: 

* **Type:**  Given - basic
* **Difficulty:** 1/10

>**Which one of the following could be the order in which the six groups are evaluated?**

(A) judges, police officers, teachers, medical doctors, nurses, lawyers (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 3]]

(B)  judges, teachers, medical doctors, lawyers, police officers, nurses (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 4]]

(C) medical doctors, judges, police officers, nurses, teachers, lawyers (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 5]]

(D) teachers, lawyers, police officers, nurses, medical doctors, judges (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 6]]

**(E) teachers, medical doctors, judges, police officers, nurses, lawyers** (*Correct*)

[[☃ explanation 7]]

---

options.explanation: This breaks Rule 3, which is that the **Nurses** and **Police** must be next to each other in some order. Here, they’re not adjacent.
This breaks Rule 4, which is that the **Police** have to be *between* the **Judges** and **Lawyers**. Here, the **Police** are not between those two elements.
This breaks Rule 1, which is that the **Teachers** must be sometime before the **Medical doctors** and the **Nurses**. Here, the **Medical doctors** are before the **Teachers**, which can’t happen.
This breaks Rule 2, which is that the **Medical doctors** must be sometime before the **Lawyers**. Here, the **Medical doctors** are *after* the **Lawyers**.
**This doesn’t break any of the setup rules.**

content:
###Question 2: 

* **Type:**  Given - could
* **Difficulty:** 2/10

>**Which one of the following groups could be evaluated sixth?**

We already made these deductions when we created Scenarios! In Scenario 1, only the **Lawyers** could be 6th, and in Scenario 2, only the **Judges** can be 6th. One of these must be our answer.

**(A) judges** (*Correct*)

[[☃ explanation 8]]

(B) medical doctors (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 9]]

(C) nurses (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 10]]

(D) police officers (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 11]]

(E) teachers (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 12]]

---

options.explanation: This isn’t possible in either Scenario. In Scenario 1, **Nurses** can’t be last because of the **Lawyers** after them, and in Scenario 2, **Nurses** have to be 4th or 5th.
This isn’t possible in either Scenario. In Scenario 1, **Police** can’t be last because of the **Lawyers** after them, and in Scenario 2, **Police** have to be 4th or 5th.
This isn’t possible in either Scenario. In Scenario 1, **Teachers** can’t be last because of the **Medical doctors** and **Lawyers** after them, and in Scenario 2, **Teachers** have to be 1st.
**This is possible in Scenario 2, for example: TMLPNJ**
This isn’t possible in either Scenario. In Scenario 1, **Medical doctors** can’t be last because of the **Lawyers** after them, and in Scenario 2, **Medical doctors** have to be 2nd.

content:
###Question 3: 

* **Type:**  New info - could
* **Difficulty:** 3/10

>**If the lawyers are evaluated at some time before the judges, which one of the following could be true?**

When working with Multiple Scenarios that we initially built, it’s important to determine which scenario(s) allow the new condition to occur. In Scenario 1, the **Lawyers** are *after* the **Judges**, so we can’t consider that Scenario in this specific question. So, we can use just Scenario 2 to determine what could be true.

(A) The judges are evaluated third. (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 13]]

(B) The medical doctors are evaluated fifth. (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 14]]

(C) The nurses are evaluated third. (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 15]]

**(D) The police officers are evaluated fourth.** (*Correct*)

[[☃ explanation 16]]

(E) The teachers are evaluated second. (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 17]]

---

options.explanation: This must be false. In Scenario 2, which is the only scenario that allows the **Lawyers** to be before the **Judges**, the **Judges** must be 6th.
This must be false. In Scenario 2, which is the only scenario that allows the **Lawyers** to be before the **Judges**, the **Medical doctors** must be 2nd.
This must be false. In Scenario 2, which is the only scenario that allows the **Lawyers** to be before the **Judges**, the **Nurses** must be 4th or 5th.
This is possible in Scenario 2, for example: **TMLPNJ**
This must be false. In Scenario 2, which is the only scenario that allows the **Lawyers** to be before the **Judges**, the **Teachers** must be 1st.

content:
###Question 4: 

* **Type:**  Flaws
* **Difficulty:** 4/10

>**If the police officers are evaluated fifth, which one of the following must be true?**

[[☃ explanation 6]]

(A) The judges are evaluated third. (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 1]]

(B) The lawyers are evaluated sixth. (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 2]]

(C) The medical doctors are evaluated second. (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 3]]

**(D) The nurses are evaluated fourth.** (*Correct*)

[[☃ explanation 4]]

(E) The teachers are evaluated first. (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 5]]

---

options.explanation: This doesn’t have to be true, for example in Scenario 2, where the **Lawyers** are 3rd.
This could be true (in Scenario 1) but doesn’t *have* to be true, for example in Scenario 2, where the **Judges** are 6th.
This is true in Scenario 2, but it doesn’t *have* to be true, for example in Scenario 1 we could have: **JTMNPL**
**This must be true, because it’s true in both Scenarios under this question’s given condition.**
This is true in Scenario 2, but it doesn’t *have* to be true, for example in Scenario 1 we could have: **JTMNPL**

Both scenarios allow the **Police** to be 5th. We could redraw the scenarios, but you may also be able to make the deduction from our knowledge of the rules. Just for maximum clarity, we’ll redraw both scenarios and place **Police** 5th:

[[☃ image 1]]

Now we can make deductions for each scenario.

**Scenario 1:**

* In this case, **Lawyers** must be last (Rule 4).
* That means that the **Nurses** must be 4th (Rule 3).
* The **Judges**, **Medical doctors** and **Teachers** are 1st, 2nd, and 3rd, though we don’t know the order.

**Scenario 2:**

* In this case, the **Judges** must be last (Rule 4).
* That means that the **Nurses** must be 4th (Rule 3).
* The **Teachers** are 1st, the **Medical doctors** are 2nd, and the **Lawyers** are 3rd, according to Scenario 2:

[[☃ image 2]]

The choice that **must be true** is the choice that is true in *both* scenarios—not just one of them. **Must be true** means *always* true (under the given condition that the **Police** are 5th**), no matter what.

options.alt: Two scenarios, both consisting of six horizontal bars numbered 1 through 6 from left to right. In spot 5 of each scenario is a P.
Two scenarios, both consisting of six horizontal bars numbered 1 through 6 from left to right. Scenario 1 has N in spot 4, P in spot 5, L in spot 6. Scenario 2 is complete: T M L N P J.

###Question 5: 

* **Type:**  Given - could
* **Difficulty:** 5/10

>**What is the minimum number of groups that must be evaluated after the teachers?**

[[☃ explanation 6]]

(A) five (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 1]]

**(B) four** (*Correct*)

[[☃ explanation 2]]

(C) three (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 3]]

(D) two (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 4]]

(E) one (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 5]]

---

options.explanation: This is the case in Scenario 2, but five isn’t the *minimum*. In Scenario 1, there could be only four groups after the **Teachers**: **Police**, **Nurses**, **Medical**, and **Lawyers**.

**Since our Multiple Scenarios show us the *only* two situations that could happen under this setup’s rules, we can deduce that the **Teachers** must have at least four groups that are evaluated after they are (Scenario 1).**
This isn’t accurate. In Scenario 1, we deduced above that there must be at least four groups after the **Teachers**, and in Scenario 2, there must be at least five.
This isn’t accurate. In Scenario 1, we deduced above that there must be at least four groups after the **Teachers**, and in Scenario 2, there must be at least five.
This isn’t accurate. In Scenario 1, we deduced above that there must be at least four groups after the **Teachers**, and in Scenario 2, there must be at least five.

We’re asked for the *minimum* number of elements that *must* be evaluated after the **Teachers**. We can determine this through our two Scenarios.

* In Scenario 1, the **Teachers** *must* be followed by *at least* **PN**, **M**, and **L**. That’s four.
* In Scenario 2, the **Teachers** *must* be 1st, so they must be followed by the 5 other elements.

A mixed diagram consisting of three columns labeled Wed Thu Fri. In each column are two horizontal bars. The top row of bars is labeled “morning”. The bottom row of bars is labeled “afternoon”. 

Beneath the Wednesday column is a J. Beneath the Friday column is a J with a slash through it. An L points to the Wednesday morning spot with one arrow and the Thursday morning spot with another arrow. Thursday afternoon is G. Friday morning is H. Friday afternoon is K.

##Prompt 2 - TV commercials

[[☃ explanation 6]]

[[☃ explanation 7]]*********************************************

*This initial setup is very important! Answer explanations will refer to the "Scenarios" we develop through our initial deductions.

---

options.explanation:
A television station must determine the order in which five commercials, each advertising a single product—fast food, granola, pizza, sportswear, or trucks—are to be aired during the five slots available in a commercial break. The order of the commercials is subject to the following constraints:

The pizza commercial must be aired earlier than the granola commercial.

The sportswear commercial must be aired earlier than the truck commercial.

The fast-food and sportswear commercials must be aired consecutively.

###What the setup tells us

This introductory paragraph is straightforward: we’re **ordering** five commercials into five spots. There is no grouping component to this setup. Your basic diagram might look like this:

[[☃ image 21]]

###What the rules tell us

* **Rule 1:** **Pizza** is sometime before **Granola**. We’ll use a dash to convey the *relative* order of these two commercials, though we don’t know how much space actually separates them.

* **Rule 2:** **Sportswear** is sometime before **Truck**. Again, we can note this to the side using a dash.

* **Rule 3:** **Fast-food** and **Sportswear** must be aired consecutively, so the pair is **FS** or **SF**, since we don’t know the order:

[[☃ image 22]]

###What can we deduce?

* One thing we can do is to make the **SF** or **FS** pair bigger by detecting the Repeat between Rules 2 and 3: **Sportswear** is in both rules. So, we can note this:

[[☃ image 23]]

* At this point, our two chains (**P—G** and **SF—T or FS—T**) don’t have anything in common.
* However, we don’t have to move to the questions too hastily!
* If we had, let’s say, eight elements for eight spots, and this is all we had to work with, we might make some deductions as to where elements can’t go, and move on to the questions.
* But, with a very limited number of spots (five), and a chain that already represents three of the five commercials, it makes sense to take the time to create Multiple Scenarios.
* We’ll build three Scenarios around the **SF**/**FS** pair, since they are the most concrete and thus are the most limited in where they can go:

[[☃ image 24]]

In each scenario, we only have three more spots to fill! It’s helpful to think of these kinds of real estate limitations on Test Day.

**Scenario 1:** **Fast-food** and **Sportswear** are 1st and 2nd.

* In this case, we can deduce that **Granola** *can’t* be 3rd (since it has to have at least **Pizza** before it), so either **Pizza** or **Truck** must be 3rd.
* Likewise, **Pizza**can’t be last (Rule 1), so the 5th spot must be either **Granola** or **Truck**.

**Scenario 2:** **Fast-food** and **Sportswear** are 2nd and 3rd.

* Here, **Granola** can’t be 1st (Rule 1) and **Truck** can’t be 1st (Rule 2), so
* We can deduce that **Pizza** must be 1st.
* That means that **Granola** and **Truck** are 4th and 5th, in some order.

**Scenario 3:** **Fast-food** and **Sportswear** are 3rd and 4th.

* In this scenario, **Truck** *has* to be 5th (Rule 2).
* That means that **Pizza** must be 1st (Rule 1) and
* **Granola** must be 2nd (Rule 2):

[[☃ image 25]]

Scenarios take more time to build up front, but they should allow us to be much more accurate *and* efficient in the questions. Every situation that conforms to the rules will fall into one of these scenarios, so we should be able to understand much more of what is possible and what must be true/false, now that we have Multiple Scenarios to work with.

##Prompt 3 - Oil and watercolor

[[☃ explanation 38]]

[[☃ explanation 39]]*********************************

*This initial setup is very important! Answer explanations will refer to the "Scenarios" we develop through our initial deductions.

---

options.explanation:
Over the course of four consecutive weeks, a gallery is going to show three oil paintings—*Gold*, *Hanbok*, and *Ibex*—and three watercolor paintings—*Ping*, *Roil*, and *Sails*. Each painting will be shown in at least one week, with exactly one oil painting and one watercolor painting shown per week, subject to the following conditions:

No painting can be shown in two consecutive weeks.

*Gold* cannot be shown in any week in which *Ping* is shown.

*Hanbok* must be shown in any week in which *Sails* is shown.

*Hanbok* cannot be shown earlier than the third week unless *Ibex* is shown in the first week.

###What the setup tells us

We are **ordering** paintings over the course of four weeks. On top of that, each week will include two paintings, one **oil** and one **watercolor**, so that’s a **grouping** component. That means we have a **mixed setup**. Note the way the numbers don’t line up neatly in this setup! There are three **oil** and three **watercolor** for *eight* spots. So, we can make an early deduction that **one of each type of painting will repeat exactly once**. An initial diagram could look like this:

[[☃ image 1]]

* We’re choosing to use subscripts for the **oil** and **watercolor** paintings, since the introduction tells us exactly which elements are **oil** and which are **watercolor**. It can often be easier than constantly referring to a list to remember which ones are which. 

###What do the rules tell us?

* **Rule 1:** No painting can be shown in two consecutive weeks. Note this however it makes sense to you. We like a rectangle with a slash through it, using **X** to designate any given painting.

* **Rule 2:** ***Gold-o*** cannot be shown in any week in which ***Ping-w*** is shown. It helps to pay attention to **oil** versus **watercolor**! Since our diagram has **oil** above **watercolor** in each week, it’s a great idea to keep this rule in the same orientation (vertical, with **oil** on top) as the diagram.

* **Rule 3:** ***Hanbok-o*** must be shown in any week in which ***Sails-w*** is shown. **Careful!** This *doesn’t* mean that **HS** is always a pair! It only means that *if* ***Sails-w*** is shown, *then* ***Hanbok-o*** is paired with it. But ***Hanbok-o*** could *also* be paired with a different painting. [If this feels like a challenging concept, make sure to visit [Khan Academy’s Conditional Logic articles in the Logic Toolbox](/test-prep/lsat/lsat-lessons/logic-toolbox-new/a/logic-toolbox--article--conditional-reasoning-logical-equivalence)!] So, we can note the rule down using conditional logic, as well as its logically equivalent rule that if ***Hanbok-o*** *isn’t* shown, then ***Sails-w*** *isn’t* shown that week.

* **Rule 4:** ***Hanbok-o*** cannot be shown earlier than the third week unless ***Ibex-o*** is shown in the first week. Here’s another conditional logic rule. It means that if ***Hanbok-o*** is 1st or 2nd, then ***Ibex-o*** is 1st; and by that logic, if ***Ibex-o*** is *not* 1st, then ***Hanbok-o*** must be 3rd or 4th:

[[☃ image 2]]

###What can we deduce?

* Rule 4 is intriguing, because both ***Hanbok-o*** and ***Ibex-o*** are **oil** paintings. So it isn’t possible to say that if ***Hanbok-o*** is 1st, ***Ibex-o*** is also 1st.
* That means that we can deduce that ***Hanbok-o*** is never 1st! Let’s note that directly in the diagram.
* We can also modify the conditional logic and remove the condition regarding ***Hanbok-o*** in 1st.
* Let’s stay with ***Hanbok-o*** for the moment, since it’s a Repeat element from Rule 2. 
* We know from Rule 2 that if ***Hanbok-o*** is not shown, then ***Sails-w*** can’t be shown.
* That means that ***Sails-w*** *also* can’t be 1st! 
* There’s a lot to keep track of here, but not too many more deductions we could make, so let’s move to the questions using this main diagram:

[[☃ image 3]]

##Prompt 4 - Charity booth

[[☃ explanation 82]]

[[☃ explanation 83]]*

*This initial setup is very important! Answer explanations will refer to the "Scenarios" we develop through our initial deductions.

---

options.explanation:
A charity is assigning volunteers to work at its booth at a fair that runs three days: Thursday, Friday, and Saturday. Five volunteers are being assigned: Lentz, Morse, Nuñez, Pang, and Quinn. On each day, exactly three of the volunteers will work at the booth. The assignment of volunteers to days must meet the following conditions:

No volunteer works every day.

On any day that Morse works, Lentz also works.

Nuñez works on Friday.

Pang does not work on Saturday.

###What the setup tells us

Three volunteers work a booth each day, for three days. That means we’re **grouping** volunteers into days (a group of 3 on each day). That gives us a total of nine volunteer spots to be filled by five volunteers. Numbers are important, especially when they don’t line up well! We’ll keep in mind that at least someone repeats at least once, and hopefully we get more restrictions on the numbers later on. Our initial diagram could look like this:

[[☃ image 1]]

###What do the rules tell us?

* **Rule 1:** No volunteer works every day. We can note this near the diagram. This will have implications on how the numbers work out when we make our deductions.

* **Rule 2:** On any day that Morse works, Lentz also works. This *doesn’t* mean that **ML** is a pair! It means that *if* **Morse** works, **Lentz** also works. But **Lentz** could work without **Morse**. So, we can note the conditional logic and its equivalent logic, which is that any day that **Lentz** *doesn’t* work, **Morse** *doesn’t* work.

* **Rule 3:** **Nuñez** works on Friday. We can note this directly into the diagram.

* **Rule 4:** **Pang** does not work on Saturday. We can note this in the diagram next to the Saturday row:

[[☃ image 2]]

###What can we deduce?

* Since no volunteer can work all three days, each volunteer must work either once or twice. That limits us in a much more helpful way than the introductory paragraph initially did!
* We can deduce that each volunteer must work twice, *except* for one volunteer who works only once. We can update our rule to reflect this.
* Since our numbers are so limited, we have a pretty good opportunity to build Multiple Scenarios around **Morse**. 
* **Morse** *has* to work at least once, and there are only three total days in the setup, *and* **Morse** always brings **Lentz** along, so let’s try building three Scenarios, in which **Morse** and **Lentz** are on a different day:

[[☃ image 3]]

Keep in mind that **ML** could work more than once! These Scenarios don’t assume that they can’t. But what the Scenarios accomplish is creating three situations into which *every* acceptable (rules-conforming) situation possible *will* fall. Let’s make deductions for each Scenario.

**Scenario 1:** **ML** work on Thursday.

* There isn’t much we could deduce here. It’s too open-ended. Let’s move to Scenario 2.

**Scenario 2:** **ML** work on Friday.

* This is easier to work with, since **Nuñez** already works on Friday, which means that Friday is now full.
* Since **Pang** can’t work on Saturday (Rule 4), **Pang** has to work on Thursday.
* That also means that **Pang** is the one employee who works only once!
* So, in this case, **ML** must work on Saturday as well as on Friday. Why?
* If **ML** worked on Thursday and Friday in this scenario, that would leave three spots on Saturday to fill. Neither **M** nor **L** can work all three days (Rule 1), so only **Nuñez** and **Quinn** would be left to fill those three Saturday spots. 
* Since we can’t fill three spots with two people, **ML** must work Saturday.
* That leaves **Nuñez** and **Quinn** to be the remaining two Thursday workers.
* So, **Quinn** must be the third Saturday worker so that **Nuñez** isn’t working every day (Rule 1).
* This scenario is completely determined!

**Scenario 3:** **ML** work on Saturday.

* In this case, either **Nuñez** or **Quinn** is with **ML** on Saturday, since **Pang** can’t be (Rule 4).
* We can’t deduce much more here:

[[☃ image 4]]

It’s often the case with Multiple Scenarios that one scenario will be much more complete than the other(s). What’s important is that we were able to make *some* additional deductions after breaking the setup into Scenarios. We should be able to use this final diagram to help us answer the questions more quickly and accurately.

options.explanation: * Many students find it fastest to go through the rules one by one and eliminate the choices that violate each rule. That way, you only have to go through the rules once, as opposed to if you went through the *choices* one by one and compared each with the rules.

[[☃ explanation 101]]

options.explanation: This could be false. We deduced above that in Scenario 2, **Pang** works on only one day, but that day *isn’t* Friday.

This could be false, for example:

Thu: **MLQ**  
Fri: **NPQ**   
Sat: **MLN**

* We’re given the new and temporary condition that **Pang** works only once.
* We can deduce that if **Pang** works only once, then each of the other volunteers works exactly *twice*.
* While it’s true that **Pang** works only once in Scenario 2, that’s not the *only* Scenario in which **Pang** can work only once, so we can’t limit ourselves to only Scenario 2.
* We can, however, eliminate each choice that *doesn’t* happen in Scenario 2, since that would mean that that choice doesn’t *have* to be true.
* That means we can eliminate (A) and (D) right away.
* Thinking about this in a different way, we could also deduce that since everyone except **Pang** works twice, that means that the **ML** pair definitely works twice.
* We deduced in our initial setup (when we were working out Scenario 2) that **ML** can’t work both Thursday and Friday, so 
* The **ML** pair must work either Thursday/Saturday or Friday/Saturday under this question’s conditions.
* We should have our answer! Which of the choices **must be true**?

###Question 21: 

* **Type:**  Given - must
* **Difficulty:** 7/10

>**The assignment of volunteers to days is completely determined if which one of the following is true?**

* These **completely determined** questions can test your pencil. Don’t be afraid to use it on Test Day! Only one of the choices will lead to a **fully** completed diagram.

(A) Lentz works on Thursday. (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 103]]

**(B) Morse works on Friday.** (*Correct*)

[[☃ explanation 104]]

(C) Nuñez works on Thursday. (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 105]]

(D) Pang works on Friday. (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 106]]

(E) Quinn works on Saturday. (*Incorrect*)

[[☃ explanation 107]]

---

options.explanation: This doesn’t completely determine the assignment. In Scenario 1, **Lentz** is on Thursday but we don’t know much beyond that.

**This completely determines the assignment of volunteers to days:**

* If **Morse** works on Friday, then **Lentz** works Friday too (Rule 2).
* That means that Friday is full, since **Nuñez** is already there (Rule 3).
* We’re basically following the same deductions we did when we built Scenario 2!
* **Pang** must be on Thursday in order to have a spot (Rule 4).
* **Pang** is the only volunteer to work only once, so
* The **ML** pair must work again on Saturday.
* **Nuñez** and **Quinn** accompany **Pang** on Thursday (Rule 1).
* That means that the other **Quinn** is on Saturday, and
* The assignment of volunteers to days is completely determined.

This doesn’t completely determine the assignment. **Nuñez** could work on Thursday in any of the three scenarios. If we placed **Nuñez** on Thursday in Scenario 3, for example, that would force **Quinn** into Saturday. But we would have too many possibilities after that.

This doesn’t completely determine the assignment. **Pang** could work on Thursday in any of the three scenarios. If we placed **Pang** on Friday in Scenario 3, we would still have too many possibilities after that.
This doesn’t completely determine the assignment. In Scenario 3, **Quinn** could be on Saturday but we still wouldn’t be able to deduce much beyond that.
